Award.AwardTitle: Documenting Isconahua (isc) in Peru: An Interdisciplinary Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will document and revitalize the Iskonawa language, one of the 30 existing Pano languages from the Amazon. Iskonawa is almost extinct, but still fluently spoken by a few elders and partially by some of their descendants, totaling around 14 known speakers. There is also an Iskonawa community of around 80 members living in voluntary isolation on the border between Peru and Brazil.

First, the project intends to develop a high-quality audiovisual database including lexical and textual material, testimonies, and ethnographic information. Second, the project will train the younger members of the Iskonawa community in re-learning the language, compiling material, documenting it and teaching it to future generations. The knowledge gained through the study of the Iskonawa language and culture will help to preserve a vast legacy of cultural production in the form of songs, rituals, dances and, mainly, oral narratives. Iskonawa represents a critical case of an indigenous language in a rapid process of disappearing. It has not been completely assimilated by the Shipibo-Konibo language, as linguists usually thought.

Recent field research (summer of 2011) has demonstrated that Iskonawa still has an independent life of its own. Specialists in different disciplines form the team of researchers. Their goals transcend just language documentation and involve ethnographic compilations, community development, language revitalization and cultural empowerment.

An important feature of this project is the training and participation of both students and native speakers in language documentation, linguistic analysis and development of materials. The project will produce a comprehensive database in a website that will organize the basic information about grammar, vocabulary and the oral tradition of the Iskonawa language and people. Part of this database will be included in a trilingual DVD (Iskonawa, Spanish, English). The project will also contribute to the better education of international public and Peruvian people about the richness of their linguistic and cultural diversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes


The knowledge gained through the documentation and study of this language has contributed in general terms to the field of linguistics as a whole, and in particular to the preservation of endangered languages in the Amazon. It has also helped to preserve a vast legacy of cultural production in the form of songs, dances and, especially, oral narratives, thus contributing to the fields of literary studies and cultural studies. We published three volumes:• The Bosquejo gramatical de la lengua iskonawa, by Roberto Zaroquiey or grammar outline has followed all international standards of phonetic notation; phonological classification, and morphologic and syntactic analysis. It is a comprehensive description of the main features of the Iskonawa language and its place within the Pano linguistic family. The volume is downloadable in one the existing websites (see below).• The Vocabulario de la lengua iskonawa or lexicon has around 1600 entries, covering most aspects of the culture and social life of the studied community. An trilingual Iskonawa-Spanish-English translation is available at the Tufts website (see below).• Tradición oral iskonawa, by José Antonio Mazzotti, Roberto Zariquiey and Carolina Rodríguez Alzza is a selection of songs and tales by members of the Iskonawa community. In compiling a selection of oral narratives and video recordings, we took into consideration their accessibility to a broad sector of the general public - an accessibility that will help to the preservation of the rich cultural legacy of this indigenous community. Many other videos are stored in the websites creeated for this project.

The websites

Most of the material is deposited in the AILLA, Tufts and PUCP’s websites created for this project.• AILLA (Archive of Indigenous Languages of Latin America, University of Texas, Austin):https://www.ailla.utexas.org/islandora/object/ailla%3A256718• Tufts University Iskonawa page:  https://sites.tufts.edu/iskonawa/• PUCP (Pontificia Universidad Católica del Perú): http://repositorio.pucp.edu.pe/index/handle/123456789/124187

Broader impacts of this project

An important feature of this project was the training and participation of both students and native speakers in language documentation, linguistic analysis and development of materials. There is an interest among native speakers and their children to re-learn the language, thus working towards its revitalization.The·project has produced audiovisual material, a socio-historic study of the language, an explanation of its grammar, a vocabulary, and a printed selection of its oral tradition. The websites create the possibility of incorporating many more projects related to other endangered languages in Peru through hyperlinks, thus centralizing the wealth of information that remains dispersed in different collections and research publications (including doctoral and MA theses and independent projects). In this way, the project contributes to raising the awareness of Peruvian people about the richness of their linguistic and cultural diversity, and to preserve important documentation about this moribund language for future researchers.
